p: Malini et al. [ 81] determined that bacterial growth appeared to be inhibited by the CS/ZnO NC membrane, while Gram-positive Bacillus substili seemed to be less vulnerable to this process than Gram-negative Klebsiella planticola [ 105]. Al-Naamani et al. [ 106] found that following a 24 h incubation period, chitosan-ZnO nanocomposite showed an excellent inhibition of bacterial growth including Salmonella enterica, E. coli, and S. aureus. Furthermore, polyethylene films (PE) subjected to CS-ZnO NC coatings prevented the formation of food pathogens completely [ 43, 52, 83, 107]. Carvalho et al. [ 13] indicated that a smaller the particle size encouraged an elevated concentration of nano or micro particles, therefore increasing the inhibiting efficiency. On the other hand, as Arfat et al. [ 83] reported that the FPI/FSG films incorporated with 100% BEO and ZnONP exhibited strong antibacterial activity against L. monocytogenes and P. aeruginosa.
